          Tom Philpott, a campaigning organic farmer from North Carolina, said there were many more nutritious ways of feeding people cheaply.

          “You can get a pound of organic brown rice and a pound of red lentils for about £1.30 each”, Mr Philpott said.

          I decline comment.

      • Guy in TN says:
        November 23, 2017 at 11:22 pm

        the efficiencies you identify are also those that the capitalist system uses to produce cheap food for consumers.

        Watchman and manwhoisthursday, this is a good point. The infrastructure and efficiency from centralization already exists, and businesses have put it all in place.

        Ideally, perhaps the government could designate certain currently existing restaurants as food stamp recipients, with an emphasis on fresh, healthy food. Government-corporate collaboration in this seems like the best option here.

    • moscanarius says:
      November 23, 2017 at 4:44 pm

      The last government-ran food provider I went to (the canteen at a military base) was not a Lord of The Flies-esque dystopia. So I’m thinking the fears of it being socially nightmarish are overblown.

      It would be absurdly scary if a military base canteen could not keep a minimum of discipline. Civil society has greater troubles achieving this, though.

    • powerfuller says:
      November 24, 2017 at 6:58 am

      @Guy in TN

      “There is much efficiency to be gained in not having to prepare your own food.”

      There’s also a tremendous amount of waste in the collective preparation of food. Individuals and families are far better able to accurately prepare the amount of food they need than a collective kitchen is able to prepare the amount of food a neighborhood needs. Free communal dining tends to lead to people over-consuming or wasting food. Some researchers argue communal dining exacerbated the Chinese famine (see Chang, G.H., & Wen, G.J. (1997). Communal dining and the Chinese famine of 1958-1961. Economic Development and Cultural Change, 46, 1-34 or Yuan Liu, James G. Wen, Xiahai Wei, (2014) “Communal dining system and the puzzle of the Great Leap Famine: Re-examine the causality between communal dining and the famine”, China Agricultural Economic Review, Vol. 6 Issue: 4, pp.698-716.). Anecdotally, consider how people tend to eat more at an all-you-can-eat buffet than they would otherwise, or how much food is thrown away in a restaurant kitchen, or how kids in school cafeterias tend to throw away all the vegetables they’re supposed to eat. There may be a lot of time efficiency gained from having one cook versus a hundred, but there’s a lot of material inefficiency as well.

      • Guy in TN says:
        November 24, 2017 at 8:40 am

        If this waste from centralized preparation is are as bad as you say, then that’s not just criticism of the American Restaurant idea, but a criticism of restaurants in general. Would you propose that we should try to de-restraunt our society, and decentralize food preparation back to our own homes? I’ve heard others propose something along these lines, but more for labor-relation reasons.

        • powerfuller says:
          November 24, 2017 at 9:36 am

          I just wanted to point out the question of efficiency is more complicated than your comment suggests. If the monetary and environmental cost of the wasted food is low enough, then it would be worth the cost for the gains in timed saved. Individuals and restaurants have to cover the costs of their own wastes — if I throw out half a meal, it’s my money, and if I’m running a very inefficient restaurant, I’ll have to raise prices and probably drive away customers. With a free (i.e. tax-paid) government service, these incentives get distorted, and people are less likely to be conscientious of their own waste. I don’t think it’s necessary to ban restaurants (or install monitors to make sure I eat everything I buy), but I don’t think it’s a good idea to expand the buffet model either. If we’re discussing this proposal, we should look at relevant historical examples to see what problems could arise. For the record, I don’t think a Free American Diner would trigger a famine; it would just be another unnecessarily wasteful government program.

  66. Nicholas Conrad says:
    November 23, 2017 at 11:50 am

    I agree with your logic on a theoretical level, but we also have empirics we can bring to bare. Governments already run numerous free or very low cost food institutions with exactly the mission as described: providing nutritionally balanced meals of reasonable tastiness. Ask anyone who’s tried prison food, or eaten at a military mess hall how well that works out in the tastiness axis. We also hear all kinds of horror stories about the quality and freshness of ingredients used in such institutions. Okay, okay, prisons and the military are pretty specialized microcosms, and they’re also optimizing for calories per dollar (though, presumably even the American Free Diner would have to set some kind of budget for their meals too). Robinson may also object that the kind of people running military and prison kitchens are obviously not the paragons of civic virtue he has in mind for AFD. So let’s look at an institution run by exactly the kinds of civic-minded people Robinson would trust with his own kids: public school administrators.

    There is no shortage of shenanigans in school lunch programs from re-defining various condiments, or even pizza as fruits or vegetables to game serving requirements, widespread fiscal abuse and mismanagement, and millions of kids choosing to go hungry rather than eat free meals compliant with Obama’s school lunch regulations.

    • manwhoisthursday says:
      November 23, 2017 at 2:14 pm

      I mentioned above that public schools are basically glorified baby sitting services of only tolerable quality. For example, would younger kids really prefer to spend time with their teachers or their parents? And, when it comes to older kids, keep in mind that Jr. High and High School are basically hives of abuse. Even the things kids enjoy about school, like friendship and socializing with peers, are provided by the other kids, not the system itself, and would happen absent the school’s existence anyway. School is just where all their potential peers are currently mandated to be.

    • nzk says:
      November 26, 2017 at 4:55 am

      Hi,
      I actaully ate in a military mess hall for ~5 years, so I can tell you how it went.
      The base was actually in an urban area, with mixed populations.
      1) The mess hall operated on very fixed schedule, and provided mostly lunches.
      This means you can’t “come in and take an apple” – only during lunch hours. it would be closed for cleaning,
      and for preparing for the next meal.
      2) The food was rationed, in the sense that the main dish was rationed to one portion. other foods, like
      salads, carbs, fruits, were free for all.
      3) The food quality itself was fine for most people. In the sense that even high ranking officers that could afford eating out ate in it regularly. It did save time, though. The drive to eat out and ordering would take something like 45min-hour, compared to ~30min in the base.
      4) This being an army setting, there was a strict dress code (uniforms), and base sergeant keeping order with the authority to throw to jail anyone miss-behaving. This was unnecessary almost at all times.
      5) The cost was very low. The estimates I heard were about 3-4$ per meal, per soldier.
      6) Even though the majority ate in the mess hall, there was a significant portion of soldiers, especially female soldiers, bringing food from home. This is probably because the military food was on the fat side.

      So over all, this public food thing can work, in a very strict sense –
      you need extreme authority to prevent problems, a way to enforce decent presentation, strict operating hours, and probably an option to cope out and get the value in cash if you decide not to use it.
      Also, since a lot of people, including officers ate there, there was managerial focus on it not to degrade.
      I think that is the main issue.

  67. sloppydopp says:
    November 23, 2017 at 8:23 pm

    An aside on corn:

    Corn in particular is heavily supported, so much so that corn farmers end up with way more corn than anyone knows what to do with. Around the 1980s, they finally hit upon a solution: high-fructose corn syrup.

    Federal farm subsidies, amounting to about $20 billion per year, are twinned with a sugar tariff to stack that deck in favor of HFCS.

    […]

    The brain-dead-obvious solution is to eliminate both taxes and even things out, right? Well, two words scuttle that idea: Iowa caucuses. As long as a corn-producing state holds the definitive first primary, we’re going to have pro-corn presidents.

    It’s hard to overstate how little corn grown in the United States is consumed by humans directly. In 2017, according to the USDA ERS Feed Grains Database, 3.2% of corn used was made into high fructose corn syrup, and only around 10% was used for any type of direct human consumption (chart; 13.3% exported, 37.9% used for ethanol, 38.6% used as animal feed).

    With these numbers, plus the fact that ethanol production has a byproduct of dried distillers grains which are also used as animal feed, it’s hard for me to buy that high fructose corn syrup is of much relevance when talking about corn subsidies. If you want to remove or alter corn subsidies, you’d have to go up against the animal product industry at large (as corn is used as feed for every species).

    (also worth noting that the usage numbers are similar for soy)

    • Matt M says:
      November 23, 2017 at 8:31 pm

      The corn subsidies are pretty old though, right? So it seems to me that the question isn’t how those percentages stack up today, but what they were like at the time the subsidies were granted. I’m guessing they pre-date ethanol being a thing at all, and willing to think there’s a decent chance there was more human consumption relative to animal consumption back then, too.

      • sloppydopp says:
        November 23, 2017 at 9:12 pm

        Here’s the data from 1976 until now (excluding exports): (ethanol + animal feed usage) / total domestic usage has been pretty much constant at around 80-90% for that entire timespan.

        And here’s a chart showing just corn usage for ethanol production (in millions of bushels) if you’re curious.

  68. n8chz says:
    November 24, 2017 at 7:17 am

    I certainly wish there were a public option in groceries. If it helps make it palatable to those of you who are aggressive framers of things in terms of “voluntarism,” I mean (primarily) “public as in domain” more than “public as in sector.” My main reason goes to something the present blog once equated with “high modernism,” namely “legibility.” I literally crave legibility. If that makes me a bad person, so be it. If I ran the dupermarket, all the merchandise would be shelved with the “nutrition information” panel facing forward. It would be ordered by bar code, with the store’s (keyword searchable) catalog available both on in-store kiosks and the store’s website; offering the public a precise and complete mapping from vulgar product descriptions to exact shelf locations. Thing is, even if I won a big enough lottery prize to buy a large supermarket chain, I probably wouldn’t be able to run it that way due to contractual constraints, as some wholesale supplier might insist on their product having an end-of-aisle display, while the contract with some food broker might forbid their client’s product being displayed within 10 feet of anything with the same color packaging. Like Uncle Noam says, you can buy a Ford, but you can’t buy a subway. I’m guessing you probably couldn’t buy a legible (or even rationally ordered) supermarket even if you had a billion dollars.

  69. Jameson Quinn says:
    November 24, 2017 at 7:23 am

    I’m not going to wade into the question of what combination of markets and elections (and glass bead games?) is the best way to run a society. But I can, most emphatically, say that if you’re going to do elections, you should at least do them right. So using Trump as an example of how elections fail is like using the Mars Climate Orbiter crash as an example of how physics fails. If you do it wrong, of course it’s going to fail.

    As most people reading this probably know, Trump actually got just 46.1% of the vote. I happen to be in posession of high-quality polling data run in the week before he was elected (GfK panel sample with over 2000 responses at over 50% response rate) that suggests that, conservatively, at least 2.8 of those 46.1 percent of voters would actually have preferred to vote for someone else if there had been a better voting method, meaning Trump’s true support was under 43.3%. A voting method that chooses somebody with that dismal level of support, when there was another candidate in the race who got 48.2% of the vote (of which percentage at least 3.7 would have preferred to vote for someone else), is a terrible example to use for deciding whether democracy works.

    (Note: “Someone else” is defined here as somebody else on the list: Bloomberg, Castle, Clinton, Cruz, Johnson, McMullin, Sanders, Stein, Trump. This list is obviously somewhat arbitrary but it’s not a crazy list of potential candidates for a 2016 general election. And when I say “at least” in the previous paragraph, I mean that I’m rounding down a naive estimator for the number of voters in my panel who clearly stated they were that type of voter. I’ve done much more sophisticated analysis of this data using hierarchical models and demographic corrections, aka what Andrew Gelman calls “Mr. P”, but I think that the naive estimator is plenty here.)

    There are better voting methods. Granted, the Gibbard-Satterthwaite theorem shows that no voting method is perfect; all are subject to strategic distortion in at least some cases. (You thought that was Arrow’s theorem? Nope; that only applies to ranked voting methods, though the ideas it contains were certainly a basis for Gibbard and Satterthwaite’s proofs.) But my simulations of the “voter satisfaction efficiency” (that is, normalized expected utility) of different voting methods show that there are methods such as 3-2-1 voting, STAR voting, or approval voting, which can kick plurality-voting’s ass around the block.

    And if you’re talking about electing a multimember deliberative body (such as a legislature) rather than just a single executive, the best available voting methods are better yet. There’s no longer an obvious way to measure “better” as there is with single-winner methods, but good proportional representation methods can reduce the mismatch between voters and representatives down to a rounding error.

    Would an ideal democracy which used good single- and multi-winner election methods still be subject to the critiques of this OP? To some degree, of course it would. Certainly in Scott’s list of 3 democratic misalignments, numbers 1 and 2 (lies and temptation) are just as bad. But on point 3, imbalance of democratic power, things can be much much better than they are today. There are still of course power imbalances in Votopia — some people have more power to lie to or tempt their fellow-citizens, and also some are just smarter — but the voting method itself acts to help level those power imbalances, not to worsen them as it does today.

    It would be easy to give specific pathways and/or examples of how first past the post (FPTP) voting actively increases power imbalances; we’ve even had to invent words like “gerrymandering” to cover some of them. I won’t go into that deeply because I suspect most people reading here can fill in this gap for themselves, and if I try to cover this quickly I’m probably going to fall into mind-killing rhetorical shortcuts.

    So, let’s say you agree with me: Votopia isn’t perfect, but it’s a lot better than what we have today, especially in FPTP countries like the US, Canada, and the UK. Is it worth trying to fix this problem? That is, is there an appreciable chance of success on a timescale where action today matters (say, the next 10 years)?

    I’d say that the answer is an emphatic “yes”, though in this case I’d estimate “appreciable” as probably between 1% and 10% in the US, between 1% and 50% in Canada (I know less about this than the US but there are some promising developments), and between .1% and 50% in the UK (I try to follow this somewhat but still know significantly less about how things are going). I believe that I personally may be contributing as much as .05% to the US possibility, and so I’m sure that there are people reading these words who could contribute more than that if they decided to. Given that the misalignments of US democracy arguably cost the world at the very least hundreds of billions of dollars of losses per year, that’s a pretty enormous expected value.

    How could the US voting method be reformed in practice? I have two rough stories for the path that could take.

    The first, and relatively less-likely, is “single-winner reform gets grassroots momentum”. The RCV (“ranked choice voting”, though that’s a horrible name) initiative in Maine is an example of what that would look like. Thus, the organization behind that push, FairVote, would probably be an important part of that story. But I also hope that a smaller, upstart organization that I’m on the board of, electology.org, will be a part too, because the voting method we’re promoting, approval voting, is clearly superior to FairVote’s proposal (“RCV”, aka IRV).

    The second, more-likely path in my estimation is that one of the major parties takes up proportional representation as a way to neutralize the partisan advantages that gerrymandering is giving the other party. I’m not going to say either party name here but if you know anything about US politics I’m sure you can guess which is which in that story.

    Why wouldn’t the party that’s hurt by gerrymandering on net choose a way to handle that problem that doesn’t reduce their duopoly advantages? Of course, that’s a possibility. But that would mean fighting the battle state by state — on enemy ground. Proportional representation, and specifically PLACE voting, would enable doing that at the federal level.

    I’ll post some more discussion and links on these matters later today, but I want to get this first comment up now.

    • albatross11 says:
      November 24, 2017 at 11:54 am

      Jameson Quinn:

      I really enjoyed the writeup!

      Do you have a sense for how these would work with the party primary system? The final election happens on one day (or a few days, with early voting), but the primaries are spread out over a long time, and it seems like the actual votes in many states are inherently strategic, because by the time Missouri gets its primary, the voters there know that only a couple people have a realistic chance of winning.

      Also, you talked a bit about these schemes making gerrymandering less powerful. How does that work? It seems intuitively like if I can set things up so that most voting districts have a majority of Republican voters, then any voting system that correctly reflects the actual will of the voters in that district will generally be sending a Republican representative to Washington.

      • Jameson Quinn says:
        November 24, 2017 at 1:14 pm

        Re primaries: You seem to be focusing on single-winner elections (president, senate, governor, etc.). For those, my favorite practical voting method is 3-2-1 voting, and the best first step to get there is approval voting. Say one of these were put in place; how would primaries work?

        Both of these methods have a much lower need for primaries, or for that matter parties, at all. Using “effective number of candidates” (ENC) — that is, using the formula for “effective number of parties” to count candidates, which counts minor candidates as only a fraction of a candidate — FPTP breaks down badly with any more than 2 ENC, approval doesn’t begin to degrade until there’s over 4 (three major and any number of minor), and 3-2-1 still works well with over 5, though if the number goes too high voting becomes a bit of a tedious chore. So even if you got rid of primaries altogether, either of those methods would work better than what we have currently.

        That said, primaries would still serve a valid purpose to keep ENC from getting tediously high, and more to the point, I don’t see parties giving up on holding them. In a world where the general election uses a good voting method, there’s strong incentives for the parties to use the same method in the primaries.

        So yes, there would be some degree of strategic voting in the primaries, and the nature of that strategy would shift over the course of a multi-state presidential primary process. But in neither early nor late states would there be an incentive for “favorite betrayal”, that is, to cast a ballot that indicates a higher preference for some other candidate than for one’s true favorite.

        The story is similar for multi-winner elections, though some details differ.

        tl;dr: Strategy wouldn’t be a big problem in primaries under good voting methods.

        …

        Re: gerrymandering. On that, I was definitely talking about multi-winner voting reforms; that is, proportional representation (hashtag PropRep). My favorite method in that regard is PLACE voting, which is essentially partially-delegated STV (single transferrable vote) with a one-winner-per-district restriction. Voters either pick a local candidate or write-in one from another district; those ballots are converted to full preference orders by combining the endorsements and party affiliation of the chosen candidate with the voting outcome of same-party voters; and transfers proceed until there is a full set of winners with one quota each and less than a quota of wasted votes.

        Under that method, districts still exist, but ballots can be initially cast and/or transferred across district lines, so the set of winners will be proportional to the whole electorate, no matter how much parties have tried to rig the game with gerrymandering. Gerrymandering can still have some marginal effects on which candidates in each party win, but it can’t get unpopular candidates elected and it can’t create a partisan lean. For instance, if there’s a 1-dimensional ideological spectrum, gerrymandering can’t shift the median winner (except possibly by, with some difficulty, increasing the rounding error without changing its sign).

        • albatross11 says:
          November 24, 2017 at 1:45 pm

          Okay, but it seems a lot easier to get some voting reform enacted where, say, we get IRV or approval voting, but keep the rest of the structure of the political system–things like current voting districts with each representative elected from a single district [edit] and voters from that district electing that representative. In that case, I don’t see how gerrymandering becomes less powerful.

          If I’m understanding you correctly above, you’re imagining a change to the election system that includes allowing people to vote across districts. It seems like if we can do that, we wouldn’t need a new election system to bypass gerrymandering.

          • Jameson Quinn says:
            November 24, 2017 at 2:14 pm

            > In that case, I don’t see how gerrymandering becomes less powerful.

            You’re right.

            > If I’m understanding you correctly above, you’re imagining a change to the election system that includes allowing people to vote across districts.

            Yes. I’m also arguing that there is an appreciable chance this will actually happen within 10 years.

            > It seems like if we can do that, we wouldn’t need a new election system to bypass gerrymandering.

            Huh? Voting across districts, in and of itself, would imply a new voting system. It would also pretty strongly necessitate a new voting method (algorithm), because just using plurality voting with self-assigned districts would be FUBAR.

    • Jameson Quinn says:
      November 24, 2017 at 1:32 pm

      Whoops. I made a mistake on those numbers for how many of the Trump and Clinton voters would have rather voted for some other candidate from that list of 9. Those numbers (2.8% for Trump and 3.7% for Clinton) were numbers of pollees who said that, if all 9 candidates were on a plurality voting ballot, they’d strategically vote for [Trump/Clinton], but actually prefer some other candidate. That leaves out the much greater set of voters who actually did so when presented with a real ballot with 2-4 candidates rather than a poll question with 9 of them.

      Rerunning the numbers correctly gives me the more-reasonable sounding numbers of 16.5% strategic Trump voters, and 17.8% strategic Clinton voters. Subtracting those numbers from their election-night support gives a total of 29.6% of honest supporters for the winner (Trump). Winning with under 30%; that’s not even close to good democracy.

      (Of course, the margin of error on those numbers above is a few percent, you should ignore the third significant figure except as a signal that I’m using actual data here.)

      • Paul Zrimsek says:
        November 24, 2017 at 1:59 pm

        So who should’ve won instead?

        • Jameson Quinn says:
          November 24, 2017 at 2:09 pm

          Among the 9 candidates on that list, and in that election-eve poll, Sanders was the clear winner by any reasonable voting method. That’s not to say that he should have won; we don’t know if that support would have held up through an actual general election campaign. But it’s certainly a reasonable first guess.

          In reality, if the voting method had been different, there’s every probability that the candidates would have been different too. Who knows who would have won then. But it’s pretty clear it wouldn’t have been Trump.

          • Paul Zrimsek says:
            November 24, 2017 at 7:31 pm

            The Electology site assures us that approval voting “tends to elect more consensus winners”. All of a sudden I’m not so sure, even though I have a soft spot in my heart for approval voting.

            Why is winning with under 30% “not even close to good democracy” when there are four candidates on the ballot?

          • Jameson Quinn says:
            November 25, 2017 at 5:23 am

            “Consensus winners” is shorthand for an idealized median voter theorem. That is, both halfs of the one-dimensional spectrum happily approve the middle, knowing that this ensures the winner will not be any further to the other side of the spectrum. Thus, the strong equilibrium is that the median candidate wins with unanimous approval.

            Of course, in real life, nobody will win with unanimous approval, so “consensus winner” is a bit of a spherical cow. But even loosening the assumptions of the MVT to a realistic degree, the strategic equilibrium of approval voting tends to be a winner who gets over 50% of the vote. Other improved voting methods like 3-2-1 voting basically just help reach this same equilibrium even more easily/quickly.

    • albatross11 says:
      November 24, 2017 at 2:17 pm

      Imagine an approval voting[1] type election for president, split out among states and used to apportion EVs. After the primaries, I think we’d have had something like the following list of candidates[2]:

      Castle
      Clinton
      Johnson
      McMullin
      Stein
      Trump

      Does the polling data give us a good sense for who would have won the presidency? The fundamental reason for the difference between the majority vote and the EV winner would remain–there are more very populous states full of Democrats than full of Republicans, and every vote for Clinton in California past 50% +1 was wasted.

      My intuition is that Castle, Johnson, and McMullin would have gotten more votes than under the current system, but Trump would probably still have won (though the election was so close that maybe it would change). This is based on the idea that given those choices, nearly all of Trump’s voters would have approved Trump plus some subset of {Castle, Johnson, McMullin}, and nearly all of Clinton’s voters would have approved Clinton plus some subset of {Stein, Johnson, McMullin}. That is, I assume that under approval voting, neither Clinton nor Trump would have lost many of their voters, though alternatives would have gained some votes when they didn’t cost Clinton/Trump anything.

      For the third-party candidates (Johnson, Castle, Stein, McMullin), everyone who voted for them in a competitive state was more-or-less saying they didn’t think Clinton or Trump was acceptable. (We don’t care how they’d have voted in noncompetitive states.) Maybe under approval voting, Castle’s voters would also have approved Trump and Steins would have also approved Clinton, but that’s not clear to me either way. All those voters had a perfectly obvious way under the current system to say they thought Clinton or Trump were acceptable as presidents, and they didn’t take it. Johnson’s voters are in the same boat, but I imagine if they approved Trump or Clinton, they’d probably do it in roughly equal numbers and cancel each other out. McMullin’s whole reason for running was the idea that Trump was unsuitable to be president, so I can’t see any of his voters casting approvals for Trump.

      [1] This is easy to think about–I just vote for as many people as I think would do a reasonable job as president.

      [2] This assumes that Sanders and Cruz respected the results of the primary, and that only the people who actually got on the ballot in a lot of states are considered. I guess a more precise answer would come from only considering the candidates that actually got on the ballot in each state, but that sounds like a fair bit of work!

      • Jameson Quinn says:
        November 24, 2017 at 2:51 pm

        Projecting state-by-state results using a national sample of just around 2000 respondents is a bit dicey. It’s doable using demographic adjustments (“Mr. P”, with a hierarchical logit model that adjusts for race, sex, age, income, education, region, and state), but the MoEs are several percent in each state. I’ve done that, and it suggests that Clinton would have won under an approval voting EC… but also under a plurality EC, which contradicts the actual outcome.

        In other words, this is not enough data to answer your question reliably.

        But if there really were a better voting method, there would almost certainly be at least one “centrist” third party. Such a party would have a hard time beating the established power of the two big parties in an ordinary election, but with historically unpopular candidates like Clinton and Trump they might have a real chance.

        Also, though my polling data does not speak to this at all, I strongly doubt that Trump would have won the Republican primary if it had been run under a better voting method. It’s also within the realm of possibility that Clinton would have lost, though that’s less likely.

        Who would have won a match between Clinton (D), Cruz (R), and Who-knows (C)? Your guess is about as good as mine, and the answer might well depend on the details of the election method involved more than it does if you include Sanders-who-hasn’t-faced-attack-ads.

    • Jameson Quinn says:
      November 24, 2017 at 5:51 pm

      I said I would post more links on voting reform later, so here are a few:

      electology.org (The Center for Election Science): The best, though not the biggest, election method reform advocacy nonprofit. I’m biased; I’m on the board. I believe that, given the potential improvements in human and global welfare from election method reform, this is a good target for effective altruism.

      PLACE voting FAQ: a proportional representation voting method that can use existing districts and machines.

      EndFPTP reddit and slack channel; electionmethods discussion group; electology discussion group: places to discuss this stuff.

  70. adelaybeingreborn says:
    November 24, 2017 at 4:42 pm

    I’m not going to claim there’s a great alternative

    I am going to claim that. There is a great alternative. I’ve been advocating “Ophelian democracy” for a long time now and finally wrote it up in a way suitable for aspiring rationalists due to recent discussions here, on the subreddit, and on lesserwrong.com. I’ve also copied over the background reasoning from subreddit comments here: Motivation for Ophelia.

    Short version:

    Ophelia is futarchy as it would have been if a utilitarian had invented it. Instead of money, it aggregates predictions by the voters, and instead of an arbitrary function, the value to be maximized is the summed responses to questions chosen by the voters.

    • DavidFriedman says:
      November 24, 2017 at 5:42 pm

      One of the planets in the three book Torchship sf series that I mentioned approvingly a while back practices “pedestrian democracy.” Lots of small independent states with lots of different political systems; the one rule that all of them are required to have is that people are free to leave.

      The series also features hostile AI and societies with a Basic Income.

      • adelaybeingreborn says:
        November 26, 2017 at 2:50 pm

        “Pedestrian democracy” sounds like an idealized vision of exit rights, whereas “Ophelian democracy” was intended as an idealized version of voice rights.

        A friend of mine once argued in summary fashion that

        exit > voice

        He may well be right, though plainly that’s a matter for some debate. A fairly-pure system of exit rights like pedestrian democracy would run into some obvious problems (which the books might well have addressed), such as

        (0) the usual host of negative and positive externalities (e.g. pollution and national security, respectively, for readers who are not David Friedman or other famous economists),

        (1) the perennial complaint that people may have personal, social, or economic ties that fall within even one small state’s geographic territory that make exit rights very costly relative to voice rights,

        (2) the dubium about whether only people have exit rights, or people plus their movable property, as both options have big potential downsides, particularly if ordinary people aren’t well-informed of the details of their exit rights,

        (3) the problem of entry rights, without which exit rights are no different than modern nation-states, but which might have difficulty handling mass movements,

        (4) whether the state is run by an elite who may be ideologically satisfied to see their country laid waste, or if instead the elite can be replaced by the equivalent of a corporate board who are incentivized to ensure the state maximizes profit or some other measure,

        (5) or as in Scott’s “Archipelago”, since all the states are “required to have” a free-exit rule, that raises the question of who has power to enforce that rule and and how they are sufficiently well-incentivized to enforce only that rule and no others.

        …though I wouldn’t be surprised if all of these could be addressed reasonably well.

        I’d try to address them by another argument in summmary fashion:

        exit + voice > exit

        For instance, I’d totally be down with a society of quasi-libertarians adopting an overarching Ophelian democracy and then actually running day-to-day law-and-order with “pedestrian democratic” microstates. Their version of Ophelia could use a fixed set of questions about enforcing the exit rule and addressing pollution and such. It’s not perfectly aligned to stable humane operation, but it’s durn close.

        • albatross11 says:
          November 27, 2017 at 1:20 pm

          It seems like one fundamental problem with exit rights (which arises among US states, but we just live with it) is this:

          On one side of the border, we have the well-run social welfare state. Comprehensive cradle-to-grave medicine and social services and education, government provided daycare for kids, etc. In order to pay for this, we have high taxes.

          On the other side of the border, we have Libertaria, with few social welfare programs but very low taxes.

          To a first approximation, it’s rational for people who will need those social services to move to Social Welfare Land. If I’m poor and diagnosed with cancer, I’ll buy a bus ticket across the border. Or just if I’m 70 and didn’t save up enough for retirement.

          Similarly, it’s rational for people who’ve been really successful and won’t need those services to move to Libertaria. If my startup was a big success and I’ve got a few million dollars (or maybe gAu) in the bank, I can move to Libertaria for the low taxes and amazing whorehouses. I may even go get a great free education and take big risks of going bankrupt in Social Welfare Land, knowing that if things go badly, I’m still going to be okay, and then move to Libertaria when it’s clear things have gone well.

          Both directions of this migration are a problem.

          Now, one answer is that Social Welfare Land just shouldn’t exist, since it’s not stable under unlimited exit/entrance rights. But that seems kind-of broken–I mean, lots of people actually vote for and want to live in Social Welfare Land.

          • Nabil ad Dajjal says:
            November 27, 2017 at 3:25 pm

            This isn’t a problem with exit rights so much as a problem with the philosophical core of modern liberalism.

            Behind the veil of ignorance, Social Welfare Land looks great. It sets a very high floor on how far you can fall, and not that many people will hit the ceiling on how high you can rise.

            But as soon as you step out of the hypothetical and into the real world, you can be pretty sure whether you’re going to be successful or not. So why should the successful to stick around and subsidize the unsuccessful?

            Liberalism doesn’t have a compelling answer to that question, at least not without nationalist or religious sentiment to fall back on. That’s the problem that you need to solve.

          • albatross11 says:
            November 28, 2017 at 2:00 pm

            Well, one solution that works pretty well is to have it be a pretty-big pain in the ass to move after you’ve made your fortune so you get to keep from paying taxes. Wealthy people do this, but it’s not so easy to manage without going to a lot of hassle.

            Another solution is to refuse immigration by people who are likely to collect a lot more from your social welfare programs than they’re likely to pay in taxes.

            Both of these may be bad policies. They may even be wicked policies. But they’re probably relatively effective at avoiding the problem I described above.

  71. russellsteapot42 says:
    November 25, 2017 at 7:56 pm

    Has anyone else pointed out that this diner system will be rather prone to Food Riots there are shortages, or overcrowding, or just when a popular food item is taken off the menu.

    Indeed, making trouble would be the best recourse that the average visitor to such an establishment would have. Furthermore, lacking the ability to fill their home pantries, the impoverished would be much more food insecure. Imagine the desperation if shortages continue for multiple days.

    • albatross11 says:
      November 27, 2017 at 1:23 pm

      a. Does that happen in the Bom Prato restaurants in Brazil?

      b. Does that happen in the subsidized school lunch cafeterias across the US, where kids get fed either a cheap or a free meal, depending on their parents’ income (and form-filling-out skills)?

      • BlueKnight72 says:
        November 27, 2017 at 1:30 pm

        If there is one thing that the current food system in the US does well, it is that there are never shortages of anything that anyone really wants. There are sometimes shortages of the things that you want to want.

  73. humeanbeingblog says:

  74. BlueKnight72 says:

    Is it just me or did go from an argument over school vouchers to an essay basically arguing for an exit-heavy system of absolutist monarchical principalities in the space of one post? God, I love this blog.

  75. October H says:
    November 28, 2017 at 8:10 am

    Many of the established social problems identified here seem to be related to the specific nature of a cafeteria (“High School Lunch Hour,” the wealthy selecting out of the location because it means long-term proximity to everyone else, etc.), and might not apply to something like a food delivery program (think a somewhat worse Blue Apron made more affordable by its universality, or maybe Meals on Wheels without the focus on providing human interaction along with the food).

    There is a similarity with public school cafeterias and free lunch for eligible students, so I’ll note two things about my experience with them:
    1. As they exist, most public school cafeterias are terrible. They’re run by companies like Sodexo (because even bureaucracies rarely want to manage an in-house kitchen) and mostly provide junky food. Maybe there’s a better model in public college cafeterias, since bigger state schools are on large parcels of land and typically have multiple dining halls with distinct differences, just like a downtown might have multiple different types of restaruants right now, and government-provided food in well-populated areas would presumably offer different selections of different quality across an area of similar or equal accessibility.
    2. Despite how poor in quality they are, free school lunches and the expansion of free school breakfast are life-saving measures for some, and life-improving measures for many more. I have friends who could only eat three meals every day because of the opportunity. At worst, something like this exists as a supplement, not a replacement, for food stamps programs, which already don’t really provide enough food for a full meal.

    Maybe the best solution is akin to the public option + the ACA marketplace: the government provides affordable and accessible food (cafeteria or otherwise) at an especially affordable price (and food stamp eligible, perhaps even free for select groups á la medicare/medicaid), and then simultaneously continues food stamp subsidies for people who can afford and choose to go for better options in the less regulated marketplace of grocery stores and restaurants.

  76. VolumeWarrior says:
    November 28, 2017 at 12:39 pm

    Rookie mistake Scott. You got bogged down into an argument about food and corn subsidies. Should have hit the public choice angle harder instead of letting him own it by hanging a hat on it.

  77. Mercy Vetsel says:
    November 28, 2017 at 7:44 pm

    Wow! Scratch a progressive and find a totalitarian. All it took was “hey, food vouchers work pretty well” and suddenly you got this guy arguing for the Venezuela meal plan. The next logical step in this line of thinking is that a) we also can’t trust non-poor people to choose healthy food and b) we can’t have a two-tier food system.

    So…. the solution? Recognize that food is a basic human right and that social justice demands equal access to all types of food. Switch to single payer for all food including groceries and restaurants.

  78. StanFL says:

  79. pansnarrans says:
    December 7, 2017 at 11:54 am

    I guarantee you that a public cafeteria system constructed to serve rich and poor people alike would be 90%+ poor within a year. I don’t even care if it’s a good cafeteria that rich people would otherwise enjoy. It would naturally start out with an overrepresentation of poor people.

    What if you made it a really good restaurant, emphasised the health aspects and minimised the public subsidy aspects when getting the relevant laws established, and then ran TV ads focusing on really delicious food that ended with “and what’s more, it’s free!”?

  • Norwegian founders with an international team on a mission to offer the equivalent of a Norwegian social safety net globally available as a membership. Currently offering travel medical insurance for nomads, and global health insurance for remote teams.

    MealSquares is a "nutritionally complete" food that contains a balanced diet worth of nutrients in a few tasty easily measurable units. Think Soylent, except zero preparation, made with natural ingredients, and looks/tastes a lot like an ordinary scone.

    Support Slate Star Codex on Patreon. I have a day job and SSC gets free hosting, so don't feel pressured to contribute. But extra cash helps pay for contest prizes, meetup expenses, and me spending extra time blogging instead of working.

    Metaculus is a platform for generating crowd-sourced predictions about the future, especially science and technology. If you're interested in testing yourself and contributing to their project, check out their questions page

    Altruisto is a browser extension so that when you shop online, a portion of the money you pay goes to effective charities (no extra cost to you). Just install an extension and when you buy something, people in poverty will get medicines, bed nets, or financial aid.

    80,000 Hours researches different problems and professions to help you figure out how to do as much good as possible. Their free career guide show you how to choose a career that's fulfilling and maximises your contribution to solving the world's most pressing problems.

    The Charter Cities Institute is working on ways governments can set up special zones with unique legal institutions. Learn more about how this could help tackle problems from global poverty to climate change.

    Jane Street is a quantitative trading firm with a focus on technology and collaborative problem solving. We're always hiring talented programmers, traders, and researchers and have internships and fulltime positions in New York, London, and Hong Kong. No background in finance required.

    Dr. Laura Baur is a psychiatrist with interests in literature review, reproductive psychiatry, and relational psychotherapy; see her website for more. Note that due to conflict of interest she doesn't treat people in the NYC rationalist social scene.

    The Effective Altruism newsletter provides monthly updates on the highest-impact ways to do good and help others.

    AISafety.com hosts a Skype reading group Wednesdays at 19:45 UTC, reading new and old articles on different aspects of AI Safety. We start with a presentation of a summary of the article, and then discuss in a friendly atmosphere.

    Beeminder's an evidence-based willpower augmention tool that collects quantifiable data about your life, then helps you organize it into commitment mechanisms so you can keep resolutions. They've also got a blog about what they're doing here

    Giving What We Can is a charitable movement promoting giving some of your money to the developing world or other worthy causes. If you're interested in this, consider taking their Pledge as a formal and public declaration of intent.

    B4X is a free and open source developer tool that allows users to write apps for Android, iOS, and more.

    The COVID-19 Forecasting Project at the University of Oxford is making advanced pandemic simulations of 150+ countries available to the public, and also offer pro-bono forecasting services to decision-makers.

    Substack is a blogging site that helps writers earn money and readers discover articles they'll like.

    Seattle Anxiety Specialists are a therapy practice helping people overcome anxiety and related mental health issues (eg GAD, OCD, PTSD) through evidence based interventions and self-exploration. Check out their free anti-anxiety guide here

    .
